title: How to Upload and Post Video on Facebook + Easy Fixes

steps.title: Tap What's on your mind?.
steps.content: Tap What's on your mind? . This will start a new post. All Facebook videos are added as posts. You'll need to start a new post to add your video. This method also works for the Lite App and the mobile website.

steps.title: Tap Photo/video.
steps.content: Tap Photo/video . This is the first option. Your Camera Roll/Gallery will open. If you're doing this for the first time, you'll be prompted to allow Facebook to access your device's camera and storage. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the video that you want to upload.
steps.content: Tap the video that you want to upload. You can select multiple videos at once if needed. When you're finished, tap Done to add the selected video(s) to your post. You'll see a preview taking up the bulk of your new post. If you want to record a new video, skip to the next step.

steps.title: Record a new video to upload to Facebook (optional).
steps.content: Record a new video to upload to Facebook (optional). You can record a new video now instead of selecting one you've already recorded. The process is a little different for iOS and Android: iOS - Tap the Camera button in your Facebook post, and then tap the Camera again in the top-left corner of your Camera Roll. Tap the Video Camera button in the lower-right corner, then tap the Shutter button to record. Once you're finished recording, tap Use to add it to your post. Android - Tap the Camera button in your post, then tap the Video Camera button with a "+" at the top of the screen. This will open your Android device's camera to record a new video. Once you finish recording, it will be added to the list of videos that you can select.

steps.title: Add a caption or description.
steps.content: Add a caption or description. You can type some text to accompany the video post to add context and help the viewer know what they're seeing. This goes in the main text field above the video preview.

steps.title: Set the audience for your post.
steps.content: Set the audience for your post. Tap the audience menu at the top to select who will be able to view your uploaded video. If you want to keep the video private , select Only me . The video will still be posted to your timeline, but you will be the only one who can see it. If desired, you can also select an album for your uploaded video. Just tap Album to select an existing album or create a new one.

steps.title: Tap Post to upload the video.
steps.content: Tap Post to upload the video. This may take a while for longer videos. You may want to connect to a wireless network before uploading to avoid using up your data plan. Once the video is uploaded, you can find it on your profile and feed.

steps.title: Click Photo/video.
steps.content: Click Photo/video . This is underneath the "What's on your mind?" field at the top of your news feed. A new post window will open. If you aren't already logged into your account, do so now. Make sure you're using the desktop version of the website. It is not possible to upload videos from the Facebook mobile website. If you're on a mobile device and want to upload a video to Facebook, you'll need to use the mobile app. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click Add Photos/Videos.
steps.content: Click Add Photos/Videos . This will open the video uploader. Alternatively, drag and drop the video file into the Add Photos/Videos field.

steps.title: Select the video you want to upload.
steps.content: Select the video you want to upload. Facebook accepts virtually all common video formats, including mp4, mov, mkv, avi, and wmv. [3] X Research source Length is limited to 120 minutes and file size is limited to 4 GB. [4] X Research source If you want to upload multiple videos, hold Ctrl (Windows) or Cmd (Mac) as you click more videos to include them to your selection.

steps.title: Add a caption or description.
steps.content: Add a caption or description. You can type some text to accompany the video post to add context and help the viewer know what they're seeing. This goes in the main text field above the video preview. These fields are optional, but it can help other users find and understand your video.

steps.title: Select your audience.
steps.content: Select your audience. Click the drop-down menu underneath your name to select who can view the video. If you only want the video to be viewable by you, select Only me . It will still be posted to your timeline, but only you will be able to see it.

steps.title: Click Post to upload the video.
steps.content: Click Post to upload the video. After uploading, your video will be viewable by the audience you selected. All videos that you upload to Facebook are posted to the News Feed. There is no way to upload a video without "posting" it, even if the audience is just set to yourself. Long videos will take a while to upload and even longer to process. Make sure you have a strong connection before uploading large video files. Find all your uploaded videos by navigating to your profile and clicking Videos .

steps.title: Make sure your video fits the size requirements.
steps.content: Make sure your video fits the size requirements. Facebook allows videos up to 4 GB in size and up to 120 minutes in length. Make sure your video meets these requirements if you aren't able to upload it.

steps.title: Make sure the video is the proper format.
steps.content: Make sure the video is the proper format. Facebook accepts most common video formats, including AVI, MOV, MP4, and MKV. If your video is not in one of the accepted formats, you won't be able to upload it. Converting the video to an allowed format will allow you to upload it.

steps.title: Upload videos when you have a strong connection.
steps.content: Upload videos when you have a strong connection. If you're on mobile, you may have difficulties uploading if you have a spotty connection . Try to upload videos while connected to Wi-Fi with a strong signal. Uploading takes a lot longer than downloading, so you'll likely have to wait a while for larger videos to upload.
